awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Impact of evaporation and waves on groundwater dynamics in tidally influenced beaches
awd_abstract_narration:
Beaches are an important part of the coastal zone where fresh groundwater flowing to the sea mixes with salty groundwater that infiltrates from tide and wave action. The biogeochemical reactions in this zone greatly impact beach ecology and determine the contribution of nutrients and contaminants to the coastal ocean. Salinity of the water is an important factor in these reactions, so understanding the distribution of salt is critical. It is typically assumed that the maximum salinity in the groundwater is equal to that of seawater. However, concentrations 3-6 times that of seawater have been observed. Evaporation interacting with waves may be an important mechanism that could change both salinity distributions and groundwater flowpaths, due to the influence of salt concentration on fluid density. The research will provide an intensive field and laboratory experience for two graduate students and undergraduates from diverse backgrounds who will be recruited in collaboration with the Educational Opportunity Program that serves under-represented minority students at New Jersey Institute of Technology. The project will provide a unique learning experience for students.  

This research will generate new understanding in three primary areas. (1) Model development and upscaling will build on recent advances in modeling evaporation and wave dynamics in beach aquifers by combining these processes to account for water, vapor, and heat transport in the porous medium coupled to subsurface hydrodynamics that incorporate wave action. (2) Data collection will include a set of detailed measurements of beach salinity and hydrodynamics at three field sites in Delaware to better understand these coupled effects in real systems. (3) Site-specific and sensitivity analyses will generate new understanding of the primary controls on evaporation-induced salinity dynamics and the resulting effects on flow physics in intertidal mixing zones. By extending analysis over a range of climatic, hydrogeological, and oceanic conditions, results will capture the range of effects and pinpoint conditions under which it is most important to consider these processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Impact of evaporation and waves on groundwater dynamics in tidally influenced beaches

Principal Investigators: Michel C. Boufadel, Holly Michael, and Xiaolong Geng 

 

Project Outcomes, Reporting Period 2/15/22-2/14/25

 

Intellectual Merit:

This project advanced the understanding of how integrated coastal drivers, including evaporation, tides, and waves, influence groundwater flow and salinity dynamics in coastal zones through a combination of field measurements and numerical modeling. Our research revealed that hypersalinity can develop in swash zones, driven by evaporation-induced groundwater upwelling and wave-driven seawater infiltration, which can significantly impact near-surface groundwater quality, salinity levels, and ecosystem health. The interaction between swash inundation and evaporation leads to complex salinity variations beneath the swash zone. Notably, the highest evaporation rates on the swash zone surface do not always correspond to the greatest elevations of salt concentration within the swash zone. This is because optimal moisture levels are also required— conditions that are neither too dry to limit evaporation nor too wet to dilute accumulated salt near the surface. We also show the influence of evapotranspiration on salinity distributions along the marsh-upland interface. Evapoconcentration was shown to vary with position along the marsh-upland boundary and with land use - agricultural sites exhibited enhanced evapoconcentration compared to forested sites.

Our results also show evaporation causes groundwater and solutes to upwell from deep sediments to the surface; as the solute reaches the surface, evaporation enhances the accumulation of the solute near the surface, resulting in higher solute concentrations than in deep sediments.

 Through the development of state-of-the-art predictive models and data collection in a range of coastal settings, we improved the ability to quantitatively predict groundwater flow and salinity fluctuations under changing environmental conditions. These findings are important for ecological and biogeochemical processes in coastal zones. The insights improve our understanding of how coastal aquifers respond to climate variability, sea-level rise, and anthropogenic stressors.

The findings from this project have been published in 6 Q1-ranked journal articles and presented at 3 national conferences, contributing to advancements in coastal hydrology, hydrogeology, and environmental management.

 

Broader Impacts:

Beyond scientific contributions, this project had a broader impact on education and workforce development, supporting the training of one postdoctoral researcher, three PhD students, two graduate students and one undergraduate student, all of whom gained hands-on experience in groundwater modeling, field data collection, and hydrogeological analysis. Additionally, Dr. Xiaolong Geng, who was a postdoctoral researcher at the time of the project’s inception, has since transitioned to an assistant professor role in the Earth Science department at the University of Hawaii at Manoa, demonstrating the project’s role in fostering early-career researcher development.

By integrating predictive models with field-based observations, this research supports coastal sustainability and resilience efforts in vulnerable nearshore environments. These findings help guide policymakers, researchers, and environmental agencies in addressing the long-term impacts of extreme weather events, saltwater intrusion, and groundwater sustainability in coastal regions.
